## Service Introduction meeting
# docs#develop#sdk-review.md

# Request an SDK Architecture Review

## Service Introduction meeting

Before requesting your first SDK Architecture Review,
teams new to the Azure SDK Architecture Board must schedule a Service Introduction meeting.
This meeting is a one-time requirement that introduces your service to the Architecture Board
and establishes the foundation for all future SDK reviews.

### When a Service Introduction meeting is required

A Service Introduction meeting is required if:
- Your team has **never** had an SDK Architecture Review with the Azure SDK Architecture Board
- This is your service's first interaction with the Architecture Board
- Your service is new or undergoing a significant redesign

### Purpose of the Service Introduction meeting

The Service Introduction meeting helps:
- Introduce your service's purpose, target scenarios, and customer personas
- Establish relationships between your team and the Architecture Board
- Discuss and agree upon library names for each language
- Identify potential design challenges early
- Ensure alignment with Azure SDK guidelines from the start
- Set expectations for the SDK review process

### What to prepare for the Service Introduction meeting

Bring the following to your Service Introduction meeting:
- **Service overview**: What problem does your service solve?
- **Target scenarios**: Who are your customers and what will they do with your service?
- **Proposed library names**: Suggested names for your libraries in each language
- **API approach**: Is your API spec complete or in progress?
  - Include a link to your completed or in progress TypeSpec project in the
  [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs][Azure REST API Specs] repo.
- **Timeline**: When do you plan to release beta and GA versions?
- **Questions**: Any specific concerns or questions about the SDK review process?
> [!TIP]
> You can prepare this information in a Word document or PowerPoint presentation to share during the meeting.

### How to schedule a Service Introduction meeting

1. **Send an email** to [azsdkarch-help@microsoft.com][azsdkarch-help]
2. **Subject line**: `[Service Name] Service Introduction Meeting Request`
3. **Include**:
   - Service name and brief description
   - Attach your Word document or PowerPoint presentation with the prepared information from the
   "What to prepare" section above
   - Preferred meeting date
     - Note: The Architecture Board typically meets between 2PM-4PM Pacific time. If this doesn't work for your team,
     specify alternative times and we'll coordinate accordingly.
   - List of attendees from your team

### What to expect from the Service Introduction meeting

The Service Introduction meeting typically:
- Lasts 30-60 minutes
- Includes architects from the Azure SDK Architecture Board
- Discusses the prepared materials (service overview, target scenarios, API approach, timeline)
- Aligns on and agrees upon library names for each language
- Focuses on understanding your service and identifying potential SDK design considerations
- Results in guidance on next steps for your SDK development and review process
**After your Service Introduction meeting**, you can proceed with requesting your
Beta SDK Architecture Review when your SDKs are ready."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md","document_title":"bad","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-suppressions","content":"# bad

## Overview
### 📦 Ready to release your first Beta (Preview) SDK?
# docs#develop#sdk-review.md

# Request an SDK Architecture Review

## Overview

### 📦 Ready to release your first Beta (Preview) SDK?

**→ [Beta (Preview) Review](#beta-preview-review)**
Request a Beta review when you're preparing to release the first preview version of your SDK for one or more languages.
**Requirements**:
- Completed your Service Introduction meeting
- API specifications are finalized
- At least one SDK language is ready for review
- CI quality gates are passing for all libraries in the review
**What's reviewed**: Library API design and code samples demonstrating hero scenarios.
> [!IMPORTANT]
> You only need to request a Beta review for your **first beta release**.
> Subsequent beta releases do not require an Architecture Board review."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"docs#develop#sdk-review.md","document_title":"Request an SDK Architecture Review","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-review","content":"# Request an SDK Architecture Review
## Stable (GA) Review
### What to expect in a Stable Review
# docs#develop#sdk-review.md

# Request an SDK Architecture Review

## Stable (GA) Review

### What to expect in a Stable Review

After you submit your review request:
> [!TIP]
> For a more detailed description of the async review process, see the [Async review workflow](#async-review-workflow) section.
1. **Material verification** (1-2 business days): ArchBoard Operations/PM confirms completeness, validates CI checks,
and flags any elevation needs
2. **Async architect review** (1 week for initial feedback): Architects review all Tier 1 language APIViews and provide
feedback via:
   - Comments directly in APIView for language-specific feedback
   - Email responses for cross-language discussions
3. **Iteration** (ongoing): You address feedback and respond to questions. Architects provide additional comments as needed.
4. **Approval** (when feedback addressed): Once approved, you'll receive sign-off to proceed with your GA release
> [!NOTE]
> **Expected timelines**: First feedback typically within 1 week; review completion typically within 2-3 weeks.
> These are estimates and may vary depending on the size and complexity of the library and changes.
> Times may be longer during holidays and prior to large conferences like Microsoft BUILD, GitHub Universe, and Ignite."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"docs#develop#supporting-sdk-customers#codeowners.md","document_title":"CODEOWNERS","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/supporting-sdk-customers/codeowners","content":"# CODEOWNERS
## Getting assigned as a reviewer on pull requests
# docs#develop#supporting-sdk-customers#codeowners.md

# CODEOWNERS

## Getting assigned as a reviewer on pull requests

The Azure SDK and Azure REST API Specs GitHub repositories utilize GitHub's built-in features for automatically adding PR (Pull Request) reviewers using the `CODEOWNERS` file.
To update who is automatically added as a reviewer when PRs are opened to your service's API Spec or libraries, locate the relevant block in the `CODEOWNERS` file by searching for the `service label` and update the GitHub aliases listed:
\`\`\`text
// PRLabel: %<Service-Label>
/sdk/<your-service-library-directory>/                  @fakeUser1 @Azure/fakeTeam1
\`\`\`
See the [Creating and editing a service in CODEOWNERS files](#creating-and-editing-a-service-in-codeowners-files) section to properly update your service's entry."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"docs#develop#sdk-review.md","document_title":"Request an SDK Architecture Review","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-review","content":"# Request an SDK Architecture Review

## Getting mentioned on issues
# docs#develop#supporting-sdk-customers#codeowners.md

# CODEOWNERS

## Getting mentioned on issues

Our repositories have automated processes for adding comments to issues when certain labels are added. Your team can automatically have a GitHub alias or GitHub team mentioned in an issue if the service's label and the `Service Attention` label are added to the issue. The `Service Attention` label signifies that the issue cannot be resolved by the Azure SDK team. The responsibility to resolve the issue will be on your team.
To update who gets automatically mentioned in issues related to your service, locate the relevant block in the `CODEOWNERS` file by searching for the `service label` and update the GitHub aliases listed:
\`\`\`text
// ServiceLabel: %<Service-Label>
// ServiceOwners:                                        @fakeUser1 @Azure/fakeTeam1
\`\`\`
See the [Creating and editing a service in CODEOWNERS files](#creating-and-editing-a-service-in-codeowners-files) section to properly update your service's entry."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"docs#design#api-spec-gen-sdk-config.md","document_title":"SDK generation configuration","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-spec-gen-sdk-config","content":"# SDK generation configuration
## Enable SDK generation
### [TypeSpec](#tab/typespec)
# docs#design#api-spec-gen-sdk-config.md

# SDK generation configuration

## Enable SDK generation

### [TypeSpec](#tab/typespec)

Add the specific SDK language emitter settings to `tspconfig.yaml`. For example, to generate CSharp SDK code from your TypeSpecs:
1. Add `@azure-typespec/http-client-csharp-mgmt` to the `options` settings in `tspconfig.yaml`.
2. Refer to the 'ContosoWidgetManager' samples to set the default values for each SDK language emitter:
    - For management plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.Management tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-mpg).
    - For data plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.WidgetManager tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-dpg).
\`\`\``
"@azure-typespec/http-client-csharp-mgmt":
    namespace: "Azure.ResourceManager.Contoso"
    emitter-output-dir: "{output-dir}/{service-dir}/{namespace}"
\`\`\``"}]

rows.inputs.query:
title: Reusing Release Plans from Preview to GA

question: I have created a release plan for my service for public preview. Can I reuse this release plan for my GA SDK release?
rows.inputs.ground_truth:
You cannot simply reuse your public preview release plan for your GA (General Availability) SDK release. Each major milestone (public preview, GA, etc.) requires its own release plan in the Azure SDK Release Planner. The GA release plan will have additional requirements, such as more comprehensive testing, additional samples, and potentially a final architecture review. You should create a new release plan specifically for your GA SDK release to ensure all required steps and validations are tracked and completed. The release planner helps you track your progress and ensures you meet all the prerequisites for a GA release.
However, you can use your public preview release plan as a reference or template to speed up the creation of your GA release plan, but it is important to go through the official process and create a dedicated GA plan.
If you have already completed some steps during public preview (such as generating SDKs or completing reviews), those may not need to be repeated, but you must still document and track them in the GA release plan.
rows.inputs.response: You cannot directly reuse the same release plan created for your service's public preview for the General Availability (GA) SDK release. Each release phase (preview and GA) requires its own release plan to ensure that all requirements, validations, and approvals specific to that phase are properly tracked and completed. For GA release, you must create a new release plan that reflects the updated scope, timelines, and any changes since the preview. This ensures compliance with the Azure SDK approval release guidelines and enables proper tracking in the release pipeline. However, you can use the information and structure from your preview release plan as a reference when creating the GA release plan to streamline the process.

For information about the CSV fields see the [CSV field README](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/eng/README.md#csv-fields). ##### CSV fields Relevant fields in the CSV for docs generation are: - **Package** -- Name of the package (e.g. `Azure.Storage.Blobs`) - **VersionGA** -- The latest GA version of the package (e.g. `12.8.0`) - **VersionPreview** -- The latest preview version of the package (e.g. `12.9.0-beta.1`) - **DisplayName** -- Display name of the package in the table of contents (e.g. `Storage - Blobs`) - **ServiceName** -- Name of the service (e.g. `Storage`) - **MSDocService** -- Used to ensure correct metadata for the docs site. Use an appropriate value for the service as defined in the [taxonomy service (filtered by **ms.service**)](https://taxonomy.learn.microsoft.com/TaxonomyServiceAdminPage/#/taxonomy/detail/2023-01-27T09:00:06.1263332Z!5a3ccca6-19ce-4f32-b516-88038fa259ae/ms.service) (Related: [taxonomy documentation](https://review.learn.microsoft.com/en-us/help/platform/metadata-taxonomies?branch=main#msservice)). - **Type** -- Use values `client` or `mgmt` to place the package in the appropriate location in the table of contents. For more information on CSV fields, see: [metadata CSV readme](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/eng/README.md#csv-fields) #### Service-level overviews Service-level overviews provide a list of relevant packages. Service-level overview pages are generated automatically for each service and contain a list of packages. rows.inputs.query:
title: Target Branch Selection for Onboarding New Resource Types

question: General I have created a PR to onboard new resource types. Is this the right target branch?
I was suggested to use azure-rest-api-specs-pr/RPSaaSMaster (private) Or azure-rest-api-specs/main (public) as the target branch?
I am getting branch protection error with the current PR.
Link to PR : https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/23390
Thank you for the help!
rows.inputs.ground_truth:
When onboarding new resource types (especially for ARM/Control Plane APIs), the right target branch depends on the stage of your API and whether your work should be public or private:
If your resource types are still under development or in private preview (not ready for public visibility), you should target the RPSaaSMaster branch in the private repo: azure-rest-api-specs-pr.
Once your API is ready for public preview or GA, you should target the main branch in the public repo: azure-rest-api-specs.
You mentioned getting a branch protection error. This is likely because the main branch in the private repo is read-only and mirrored from the public repo. You cannot merge directly into main in the private repo. For private work, use RPSaaSMaster. For public release, use main in the public repo.
Summary:
Use azure-rest-api-specs-pr/RPSaaSMaster for private onboarding and early-stage work.
Use azure-rest-api-specs/main for public onboarding and final publishing.
If you need to update your PR, change the target branch to RPSaaSMaster in the private repo for onboarding new resource types. If your resource is ready for public consumption, move it to a PR against the public repo's main branch.
Let me know if you need help updating your PR or have questions about the process!
rows.inputs.response:
You should target the appropriate release branch in the correct repository based on whether your onboarding is for a private or public API spec. For onboarding new resource types:

- If your API spec is not yet public, you should use the private repo (azure-rest-api-specs-pr) and target either 'RPSaaSMaster' or 'RPSaaSDev' as your base branch. These branches are specifically designated for private onboarding and development before public release.
- If your API spec is ready for public onboarding, you should use the public repo (azure-rest-api-specs) and target the 'main' branch.

Branch protection errors typically occur if you attempt to merge directly into a protected branch (such as 'main' or 'RPSaaSMaster') without following the required process. The correct workflow is:
1. Create a topic branch from the appropriate release branch (e.g., 'RPSaaSMaster' in private repo or 'main' in public repo).
2. Submit your PR against the release branch, not directly against 'main' or 'RPSaaSMaster'.

This ensures compliance with branch protection rules and allows for proper review and CI validation. If you are getting a branch protection error, double-check that your PR is not trying to merge directly into a protected branch. Instead, create a topic branch off the release branch and submit your PR against it.

Summary:
- Use 'RPSaaSMaster' in azure-rest-api-specs-pr for private onboarding.
- Use 'main' in azure-rest-api-specs for public onboarding.
- Always create a topic branch from the release branch and submit your PR against the release branch, not directly into protected branches.

If you need more details on how to create and work against release branches, see the referenced onboarding documentation.

[{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec-conversion.md","document_title":"Convert OpenAPI specs to TypeSpec","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs/api-typespec-conversion","content":"# Convert OpenAPI specs to TypeSpec
## Before you begin
# docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec-conversion.md

# Convert OpenAPI specs to TypeSpec

## Before you begin

- You have [access](xref:access) to the GitHub repositories and respective GitHub groups.
- You read our [repository branches strategy](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/policies_repobranching.html).
- You are familiarized with the [Azure SDK Architecture design guidelines](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/general_introduction.html).

### Overview of TypeSpec

[TypeSpec](https://typespec.io) is the new standard API definition language for Azure, developed by Microsoft.

# Work against the release branch

## Create a fork

1. Create a fork, which is a copy of the target repository. You only need to do this once.
   - In [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs) (public) or  
     [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr) (private) - wherever you created
     your branch above - click on the **Fork** button if you haven't already forked the repository.
     This will create a copy in developers' own profiles. Read more about [our repositories](xref:api-repos) for what is
     public and what is private.
   - Click the **Clone** button to clone the repository to your local machine. You can also just hit `.` on
     GitHub to open the repository in Visual Studio Code online.
2. Whatever tool you use, switch branches to the release branch created above, and then create a new branch.
   Call it whatever you like, but a brief, descriptive name like `add-models` is recommended.
   Using a terminal, for example, you can pull the upstream release branch and create a topic branch:
   \`\`\`bash
   git fetch upstream release-cognitiveservices-2022-03-01-preview
   git checkout -b add-models upstream/release-cognitiveservices-2022-03-01-preview

# docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec-conversion.md

# Convert OpenAPI specs to TypeSpec

This document outlines the process for converting OpenAPI specifications to TypeSpec, detailing the responsibilities of
both the service team and the Azure SDK team.

## Before you begin

- You have [access](xref:access) to the GitHub repositories and respective GitHub groups.
- You read our [repository branches strategy](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/policies_repobranching.html).
- You are familiarized with the [Azure SDK Architecture design guidelines](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/general_introduction.html).

### Overview of TypeSpec

[TypeSpec](https://typespec.io) is the new standard API definition language for Azure, developed by Microsoft.
TypeSpec offers many [benefits for Azure API definition](api-typespec.md), including consistency, efficiency, enhanced tooling,
and accessibility. By using TypeSpec, you can ensure a consistent, high-quality developer experience across Azure services.

## Conversion scope

- Horizontal conversion: Converting existing Azure OpenAPI specs to TypeSpec should not introduce any changes to the API.
- No version revving: No version revving will occur during this process. The focus is solely on converting the existing
specifications to TypeSpec.
- SDKs generated for validation only: The SDKs generated from the converted TypeSpec files will be used for validation
purposes only. They are not intended for production release.

## Conversion process

Process overview:
![Diagram showing the conversion process overview](../../img/tsp_conversion_process_overview.png)

### Create a conversion plan

Create your conversion plan inside the [Release planner tool](xref:release-plan) to manage and understand the steps
required to convert your OpenAPI
spec to TypeSpec.

### Fork and clone the repository

- Fork the repository: Navigate to the repository on GitHub and fork it to your own GitHub account.
  - [Public repo](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs)
  - [Private repo](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr)
- Clone the forked repository to your local machine:
\`\`\`bash
git clone https://github.com/your-username/azure-rest-api-specs.git
cd azure-rest-api-specs
\`\`\`

### Identify the OpenAPI spec version to convert

It must be newest version for which SDKs have been generated, regardless of whether it was a stable or preview version.

### TypeSpec conversion tool

The OpenAPI to TypeSpec conversion tool helps take on the bulk of the manual conversion labor. It handles both data-plane
 and management-plane OpenAPI specs. The produced TypeSpec relies on the Azure.Core and Azure.Resource.Manager libraries.
For detailed instructions on how to use the conversion tool, refer to the full [documentation](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/01-get-started/).
> [!NOTE]
> The conversion tool will not handle all scenarios - some manual conversion work may be required.

### Validate the conversion

1. Use the `tsp-client` compare tool: Run the following command to compare the original and converted specs:
    \`\`\`bash
    tsp-client compare --lhs openapi-specs-folder --rhs typespec-folder
    \`\`\`
    Parameters:
    - `--lhs`: The folder containing your original hand-authored OpenAPI specifications.
    - `--rhs`: The folder containing your converted TypeSpec files.
2. Address any discrepancies or issues identified by the comparison tool. The command will ignore differences in the
OpenAPI spec that don't correspond to differences in the service, allowing you to focus only on relevant differences.
3. Disable SDK generation for OpenAPI: remove the specific language from the `swagger-to-sdk` list and delete the
 corresponding `readme.{language}.md` file. For example, to disable CSharp, remove `- repo: azure-sdk-for-net` from the
 `swagger-to-sdk` block in `readme.md` and delete `readme.csharp.md` file.
 Refer to [SDK generation configuration](xref:spec-gen-sdk-config) for more details of the configuration.
> [!NOTE]
> Common post-conversion issues:
>   - Datetime warnings: Ensure that datetime formats are consistent between the original and converted specs.
>   - Casing issues: Verify that the casing of property names and other identifiers matches the original spec.

### Create a pull request with your Azure REST API spec update

1. Commit to your forked repository:
    \`\`\`bash
      git add .
      git commit -m "Converted OpenAPI specs to TypeSpec"
      git push origin main
    \`\`\`
2. Create a pull request: The process for creating pull requests with your Azure REST API spec update is documented  
[here](https://aka.ms/azsdk/specreview). Your changes will be reviewed by the ARM review board (management plane) or
 the API Stewardship Board for data plane specs.
> [!IMPORTANT]
> Your conversion plan will guide you on how to schedule the meeting with the API Stewardship Board.

### Merge the PR

- Review feedback: Go through all comments and feedback provided by the reviewers. Ensure that any requested changes
 have been made.
- Confirm approvals: Verify that all required approvals have been obtained.
- Ensure CI required jobs are green: Make sure that all Continuous Integration (CI) required jobs have passed successfully.
 The PR cannot be merged until these jobs are green.
- Merge the pull request.

### Conversion plan completion

Once you have merged your PR,  your conversion plan will automatically be closed to accurately reflect the changes in
 our records.

## Resources

- [TypeSpec Conversion Tool](https://aka.ms/typespec/conversion) to help convert OpenAPI specs to TypeSpec.
This tool automates much (but not all) of the conversion process, reducing the manual effort required.
- TCP Client Compare Tool: Used to validate the conversion by comparing the original and converted specs.
This tool helps ensure that the converted TypeSpec files accurately reflect the original OpenAPI specifications.
- [TypeSpec.io](https://typespec.io): The official website for TypeSpec, providing comprehensive documentation and resources.
- [Engineering Hub – Azure SDKs – TypeSpec](https://aka.ms/azsdk/typespec): Engineering resources and guidelines for
 using TypeSpec within Azure SDKs.
- [TypeSpec 101 - YouTube tutorials by TypeSpec team](https://aka.ms/typespec101): Video tutorials to help you get
 started with TypeSpec.
- [Azure Quantum’s TypeSpec folder (example of Azure service APIs defined in TypeSpec)](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/specification/quantum/Quantum.Workspace).

## Get help

If you need help or have questions, join the [TypeSpec Discussion Teams channel](https://aka.ms/typespec/discussions).
This is a community of TypeSpec users and experts who are ready to assist you."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"docs#develop#sdk-generate-mgmt-dotnet.md","document_title":"Generate .NET management plane SDK","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-generate-mgmt-dotnet","content":"# Generate .NET management plane SDK

`Azure.ResourceManager.ServiceLinker` is being used as our prime example for OpenAPI.
1. Use any editor to open the `autorest.md` under `src` subfolder, and update:
    - Go to the [ServiceLinker readme.md in Azure REST API Specs Repo](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/servicelinker/resource-manager/readme.md), press 'Y' key to [get the permanent link](https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/working-with-files/using-files/getting-permanent-links-to-files) and substitute the `require` value with your specific path here:
\`\`\`
require: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/{guid}/specification/servicelinker/resource-manager/readme.md
\`\`\`
> [!NOTE]
>  * You can use a local patch as the value, which allows you to test an unpublished local OpenAPI spec.
>  * When releasing your SDKs, it must refer to [the `main` branch of the public Azure REST API specs repository](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/specification). Other branches, private repos, or personal repos are **NOT** supported to release an official Azure SDK.
>  * If you need to generate SDKs from specs in [the private REST API Specs repo](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr), there is [an extra step to handle the credential for autorest](https://github.com/Azure/autorest/blob/main/docs/generate/readme.md#generate-from-private-github-repos).
    - Specify a target version using `tag` as belows if you don't want to use the default tag in [the README configuration file](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/samplefiles/README.md). For example,
\`\`\`
tag: package-2022-01-01-preview
\`\`\`
> [!NOTE]
> To ensure the preview of the corresponding .NET SDK in the API Spec PR, refrain from adding the tag here. Instead, use the default tag to generate the SDK and preview it as desired.

- Specify a target version using `tag` as belows if you don't want to use the default tag in [the README configuration file](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/samplefiles/README.md). For example,
\`\`\`
tag: package-2022-01-01-preview
\`\`\`
> [!NOTE]
> To ensure the preview of the corresponding .NET SDK in the API Spec PR, refrain from adding the tag here. Instead, use the default tag to generate the SDK and preview it as desired.
2. Run `dotnet build` command to generate the SDK code, then AutoRest will create your .NET SDK using the latest version of your API specs.
\`\`\`
dotnet build /t:GenerateCode
\`\`\`
> [!NOTE]
> Currently there could be some compatibility issues that the AutoRest tool can't handle. If you encounter generation errors, file an issue in the GitHub Repo [Azure/azure-sdk-for-net](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net) to get support.
3. Generate the API file with the following command, review it and update any SDK API if it does not follow the [.NET Azure SDK Design Guidelines](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/dotnet_introduction.html) with [mgmt configurations](https://github.com/Azure/autorest.csharp/blob/feature/v3/docs/mgmt/readme.md#management-plane-configurations) in `autorest.md`. Then regenerate the API file.
\`\`\`
<RepoRoot>\eng\scripts\Export-API.ps1 servicelinker
\`\`\`
:point_right: Replace `servicelinker` with your SDK service directory name under azure-sdk-for-net\sdk.
4. # Request an SDK Architecture Review

| Short Link: | [aka.ms/azsdk/onboarding/archboardschedule](https://aka.ms/azsdk/onboarding/archboardschedule) |
| --- | --- |

## Overview

The Azure SDK Architecture Board reviews Azure **data plane (client plane) SDKs** to ensure they are developer-friendly,
consistent across all supported languages, and follow Azure SDK design guidelines. The goal is to provide a world-class
developer experience for all Azure services.
> [!NOTE]
> **Management Plane (ARM) libraries do NOT require an Architecture Board review.**
>
> Only **data plane (client plane) libraries** are reviewed by the Azure SDK Architecture Board. 
> If you are developing management plane (ARM) libraries, you do not need to follow this process.
All Azure data plane SDKs must be reviewed by the Architecture Board prior to release.
The review process is normally conducted **asynchronously** via email and [APIView] comments.
Synchronous meetings are only scheduled when async review is insufficient for complex cross-language issues.

### 📦 Ready to release your first Beta (Preview) SDK?

**→ [Beta (Preview) Review](#beta-preview-review)**
Request a Beta review when you're preparing to release the first preview version of your SDK for one or more languages.
**Requirements**:
- Completed your Service Introduction meeting
- API specifications are finalized
- At least one SDK language is ready for review
- CI quality gates are passing for all libraries in the review
**What's reviewed**: Library API design and code samples demonstrating hero scenarios.
> [!IMPORTANT]
> You only need to request a Beta review for your **first beta release**.
> Subsequent beta releases do not require an Architecture Board review.

## Service Introduction meeting

Before requesting your first SDK Architecture Review,
teams new to the Azure SDK Architecture Board must schedule a Service Introduction meeting.
This meeting is a one-time requirement that introduces your service to the Architecture Board
and establishes the foundation for all future SDK reviews.

### When a Service Introduction meeting is required

A Service Introduction meeting is required if:
- Your team has **never** had an SDK Architecture Review with the Azure SDK Architecture Board
- This is your service's first interaction with the Architecture Board
- Your service is new or undergoing a significant redesign

### Purpose of the Service Introduction meeting

The Service Introduction meeting helps:
- Introduce your service's purpose, target scenarios, and customer personas
- Establish relationships between your team and the Architecture Board
- Discuss and agree upon library names for each language
- Identify potential design challenges early
- Ensure alignment with Azure SDK guidelines from the start
- Set expectations for the SDK review process

### What to prepare for the Service Introduction meeting

Bring the following to your Service Introduction meeting:
- **Service overview**: What problem does your service solve?
- **Target scenarios**: Who are your customers and what will they do with your service?
- **Proposed library names**: Suggested names for your libraries in each language
- **API approach**: Is your API spec complete or in progress?
  - Include a link to your completed or in progress TypeSpec project in the
  [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs][Azure REST API Specs] repo.
- **Timeline**: When do you plan to release beta and GA versions?
- **Questions**: Any specific concerns or questions about the SDK review process?
> [!TIP]
> You can prepare this information in a Word document or PowerPoint presentation to share during the meeting.

### How to schedule a Service Introduction meeting

1. **Send an email** to [azsdkarch-help@microsoft.com][azsdkarch-help]
2. **Subject line**: `[Service Name] Service Introduction Meeting Request`
3. **Include**:
   - Service name and brief description
   - Attach your Word document or PowerPoint presentation with the prepared information from the
   "What to prepare" section above
   - Preferred meeting date
     - Note: The Architecture Board typically meets between 2PM-4PM Pacific time. If this doesn't work for your team,
     specify alternative times and we'll coordinate accordingly.
   - List of attendees from your team

### What to expect from the Service Introduction meeting

The Service Introduction meeting typically:
- Lasts 30-60 minutes
- Includes architects from the Azure SDK Architecture Board
- Discusses the prepared materials (service overview, target scenarios, API approach, timeline)
- Aligns on and agrees upon library names for each language
- Focuses on understanding your service and identifying potential SDK design considerations
- Results in guidance on next steps for your SDK development and review process
**After your Service Introduction meeting**, you can proceed with requesting your
Beta SDK Architecture Review when your SDKs are ready.

## Stable (GA) Review

### When to request a Stable Review

Request a Stable SDK Architecture Review when:
- You are preparing to release a GA (stable) SDK version
- You have completed and received approval from your Beta SDK Architecture Review
- All feedback from the beta review has been addressed
- All Tier 1 languages (.NET, Java, JavaScript/TypeScript, Python) are ready for review

### Required materials for a Stable Review

Before requesting a Stable review, prepare the following:
| Material | Description | Required/Optional | Example |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **APIView links** | APIView links for **all Tier 1 languages** (.NET, Java, JavaScript/TypeScript, Python). | Required | [APIView Example] |
| **Code Samples** | Code samples demonstrating hero scenarios should be attached to the APIView. Click the puzzle piece icon on the left sidebar to view them. | Required | [Samples Example] |
| **API spec directory** | Link to API spec directory (must include `client.tsp`). | Required | [Spec Directory Example] |
| **Originating PR(s)** | Link to originating PR for each APIView. | Required | [SDK PR Example] |
| **README links** | Links to library README files for all Tier 1 languages. | Required | [README Example] |

### How to request a Stable review

1. **Prepare your materials**: Ensure all required materials listed above are ready
2. **Send an email** to [azsdkarch-help@microsoft.com][azsdkarch-help]
3. **Use the following email template**:
\`\`\`
Subject: [Service Name] [Stable/GA] Azure SDK Review
Service Name: [Your service name]
API Spec Directory: [Link to spec directory including client.tsp]
APIView links for all Tier 1 languages:
  .NET: [Link]
  Java: [Link]
  JavaScript/TypeScript: [Link]
  Python: [Link]
Originating PR(s) for each APIView:
  .NET: [Link]
  Java: [Link]
  JavaScript/TypeScript: [Link]
  Python: [Link]
CI Validation Status: [Confirm passing for all Tier 1 languages]
README Links:
  .NET: [Link]
  Java: [Link]
  JavaScript/TypeScript: [Link]
  Python: [Link]
Additional context/questions: [Optional]
\`\`\`

### What to expect in a Stable Review

After you submit your review request:
> [!TIP]
> For a more detailed description of the async review process, see the [Async review workflow](#async-review-workflow) section.
1. **Material verification** (1-2 business days): ArchBoard Operations/PM confirms completeness, validates CI checks,
and flags any elevation needs
2. **Async architect review** (1 week for initial feedback): Architects review all Tier 1 language APIViews and provide
feedback via:
   - Comments directly in APIView for language-specific feedback
   - Email responses for cross-language discussions
3. **Iteration** (ongoing): You address feedback and respond to questions. Architects provide additional comments as needed.
4. **Approval** (when feedback addressed): Once approved, you'll receive sign-off to proceed with your GA release
> [!NOTE]
> **Expected timelines**: First feedback typically within 1 week; review completion typically within 2-3 weeks.
> These are estimates and may vary depending on the size and complexity of the library and changes.
> Times may be longer during holidays and prior to large conferences like Microsoft BUILD, GitHub Universe, and Ignite.

### When reviews are elevated

Your review may be elevated to a synchronous meeting if:
- Unresolved beta feedback remains
- Cross-language design issues cannot be resolved asynchronously
- The library is strategic or complex
- Architects determine further discussion is required
If your review is elevated, ArchBoard Operations/PM will schedule a one-hour meeting to resolve known issues.
All decisions will be documented in the async review thread.

## Additional resources

- **Azure SDK Guidelines**: [Azure SDK Guidelines]
- **APIView**: [APIView]

## Contact

For questions or assistance with SDK Architecture Reviews:
**Email**: [azsdkarch-help@microsoft.com][azsdkarch-help]

[Samples Example]: https://spa.apiview.dev/samples/425998d8217d4a3b875a5d0187063ba1?activeSamplesRevisionId=f18999b016414448a4aa1218a6966095

# docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md

# Suppress validation failures on a PR

> [!NOTE]
> This article assumes you came here from your REST API specs PR.
> See [this documentation section description](xref:specs-pr-guides) for details.
On your Azure REST API specs PR, some of the GitHub check failures (see the `Checks` tab on your PR) can be suppressed.
The suppression can be either just for the PR, or permanent.

## To suppress given validation failure

1. Determine which failing check you want to suppress: see its name in the `Checks` tab in your PR.
1. Determine if you have one of the [valid suppression reasons](#valid-suppression-reasons).
1. Determine if you want to suppress the failure only for the PR, or permanently. Permanent suppression is preferred to avoid re-addressing the same issue in future PRs.
1. Consult [the suppression cases table](#suppression-cases-table) for instructions corresponding to your case.
1. If you want to apply temporary suppression:
   1. Mention in a comment on your PR the PR assignee asking to apply the suppression. Provide justification.
      See [valid suppression reasons](#valid-suppression-reasons).
1. If you applied permanent suppression:
   1. It will manifest by the PR getting a label `SuppressionReviewRequired`.
   1. Verify the suppression works by the check changing from **failed** to **neutral**.
   1. Wait until your suppression is reviewed. If it is approved, the approved will add the `Approved-Suppression` label.
   1. Understand the suppression won't be approved if it is not one of the  
      [valid suppression reasons](#valid-suppression-reasons) as explained in relevant section.

## Suppression cases table

|
| Swagger LintDiff                   | See [aka.ms/ci-fix]                       | `Approved-LintDiff`                                  | See [suppress AutoRest extension](#suppress-autorest-extension) |
| Swagger LintDiff(RPaaS)            | See [aka.ms/ci-fix]                       | `Approved-LintRPaaS`                                 | See [suppress AutoRest extension](#suppress-autorest-extension) |

## suppressions.yaml

File `suppressions.yaml` is used for all checks created in 2024 or later, like
`TypeSpec Requirement` and `TypeSpec Validation`.
For simplicity, we recommend adding all suppressions to a single file at the root of your spec folder:
\`\`\`
specification/myservice/suppressions.yaml
\`\`\`
Alternatively, you can use multiple files in separate folders.  Currently, tools will use the first
instance of `suppressions.yaml` found walking up the directory tree.  We are planning
future support for "merging" files up the hierarchy.
A suppression follows this general format:
\`\`\`
- tool: ToolName
  path: applies/to/**/*.json
  reason: Why this can't be fixed
\`\`\`
`path` uses "glob" matching.  For syntax, see https://www.npmjs.com/package/minimatch.
Scope your `path` as narrowly as possible.  For example, if a suppression only applies
to a single version of your spec:

# Publish SDK reference docs

## Onboard a released package

Follow these steps to onboard a released package to Azure SDK reference docs on Microsoft Learn.
Docs are built using CI pipelines maintained by the Docs team. Builds generate docs for all packages onboarded, run on
a schedule, and take several hours to complete. Changes can be viewed on the reference review site.
> Note: Android reference docs are not yet supported on Microsoft Learn. You will need to follow the [Android guidelines](./sdk-android-docs.md)
> for publishing said documentation instead.

### Packages released through the Azure SDK engineering system

If your package is released through the Azure SDK engineering system, almost everything is automated. You'll need to
take action if this is your first time releasing a package.
When releasing a package for the first time:
1. Ensure that your package is tracked in the  
[release work items](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/Release/_queries/query/7d106acd-a1c2-47b9-9676-996422328397/). This can be done by running the [**Prepare-Release.ps1** script](https://aka.ms/azsdk/mark-release-status).
In each item for your release, you should have a value for **Service Name** and **Package Display Name**. The docs table of contents is generated from this data.
> [!NOTE]
> Do not skip this step. If you skip the service name, your item will appear in the TOC in the **Other** > **Uncategorized** section.
1. Ensure that your package-level overview file (the README.md file for your package in the SDK source repo) is up to date
*before* releasing.
In general, the automated system will ensure that updated docs are onboarded within a day or two of your release.
To customize information about your package outside of the engineering system consult documentation for [CSV fields](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/eng/README.md#csv-fields)
and [Service Level Overview](#service-level-overview) and [Package Level Overview](#package-level-overview).
#### Troubleshooting automated documentation updates
An automation job runs every 2 hours during business hours on weekdays. If your data is
not updated and you don't want to wait, [run the job manually](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?definitionId=1284).
This will update the metadata PR.
If you find anything unexpected in the table of contents or service README, check the
[metadata CSV file](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/tree/main/_data/releases/latest) to ensure that the metadata is
correct. If the metadata is not correct, open a PR with corrections.

during business hours on weekdays. If your data is
not updated and you don't want to wait, [run the job manually](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?definitionId=1284).
This will update the metadata PR.
If you find anything unexpected in the table of contents or service README, check the
[metadata CSV file](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/tree/main/_data/releases/latest) to ensure that the metadata is
correct. If the metadata is not correct, open a PR with corrections.
Once merged your changes will be released on the next available documentation release.
##### Update a published Package-level Overview
> [!NOTE]
> For packages released using the Azure SDK EngSys, changes need to be synchronized between the source SDK repo and the docs
> repo. Changes to the docs repo that are not mirrored to the source SDK repo will be overwritten by content from the source
> SDK repo on the next package release.
1. Find the Package-level overview using the table from [Package-level overviews](#package-level-overviews).
2. Find the corresponding README.md file for the library in the SDK repo (e.g. [azure-sdk-for-net](https://github.com/azure/azure-sdk-for-net)).
3. Update the "front matter" date field at the beginning of the file to today's date. To update other front matter metadata, see [Ensure CSV metadata is correct](#ensure-csv-metadata-is-correct).
4. Copy changed content from step 2 into the Package-level overview from step 1.
5. Open a pull request for the update file in the docs repo

### Packages released outside the Azure SDK engineering system

For information about the CSV fields see the [CSV field README](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/eng/README.md#csv-fields).
##### CSV fields
Relevant fields in the CSV for docs generation are:
- **Package** -- Name of the package (e.g. `Azure.Storage.Blobs`)
- **VersionGA** -- The latest GA version of the package (e.g. `12.8.0`)
- **VersionPreview** -- The latest preview version of the package (e.g. `12.9.0-beta.1`)
- **DisplayName** -- Display name of the package in the table of contents (e.g. `Storage - Blobs`)
- **ServiceName** -- Name of the service (e.g. `Storage`)
- **MSDocService** -- Used to ensure correct metadata for the docs site. Use an appropriate value for the service as
defined in the [taxonomy service (filtered by **ms.service**)](https://taxonomy.learn.microsoft.com/TaxonomyServiceAdminPage/#/taxonomy/detail/2023-01-27T09:00:06.1263332Z!5a3ccca6-19ce-4f32-b516-88038fa259ae/ms.service)
(Related: [taxonomy documentation](https://review.learn.microsoft.com/en-us/help/platform/metadata-taxonomies?branch=main#msservice)).
- **Type** -- Use values `client` or `mgmt` to place the package in the appropriate location in the table of contents.
For more information on CSV fields, see: [metadata CSV readme](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/eng/README.md#csv-fields)

#### Service-level overviews 
Service-level overviews provide a list of relevant packages. Service-level overview pages are generated automatically
for each service and contain a list of packages.
Service teams can create their own service-level overview pages which contain more information. Service teams that
create their own service-level overview pages are responsible for updating those pages.

##### Monikers
The **\<moniker\>** should be one of "preview" for pre-release versions, "latest" for GA versions, and "legacy" for
legacy versions.
#### Metadata JSON files
Create a metadata JSON file specifying information about your package to ensure that it is properly onboarded into the
docs build system. The metadata JSON file should be named in the following format:
\`\`\`json
{
  "Name": "Azure.Storage.Blobs",
  "Version": "12.17.0",
  "DirectoryPath": "sdk/storage/Azure.Storage.Blobs",
  "ServiceDirectory": "storage",
  "ReadMePath": "sdk/storage/Azure.Storage.Blobs/README.md",
  "ChangeLogPath": "sdk/storage/Azure.Storage.Blobs/CHANGELOG.md",
  "Group": null,
  "SdkType": "client",
  "IsNewSdk": true,
  "ArtifactName": "Azure.Storage.Blobs",
  "ReleaseStatus": "2023-07-11",
  "Namespaces": [
    "Azure.Storage.Blobs",
    "Azure.Storage.Blobs.Models",
    "Azure.Storage.Blobs.Specialized",
    "Azure.Storage.Sas",
    "Microsoft.Extensions.Azure"
  ],
  "DocsCiConfigProperties": {
    "tfm": "netstandard2.0"
  },
  "MSDocService": "placeholder"
}
\`\`\`
Required fields are:
- **Name** -- Name of the package (e.g. `Azure.Storage.Blobs`).
- **Version** -- The latest GA version of the package (e.g. `12.17.0`).
- **ServiceDirectory** -- Name of the service (e.g. `storage`).
- **DirectoryPath** -- Path from the root of the `azure-sdk-for-*` repo to the package. If unknown or the package is not released from an `azure-sdk-for-*` repo, use the value `""`
- **SdkType** -- Use values `client` or `mgmt` to place the package in the appropriate location in the table of contents.
- **IsNewSdk** -- Use `true` if the package is a track 2 SDK, otherwise use `false`.
- **Group** -- Required *only for Java*

# docs#design#api-specs-pr#api-tutorial#api-tutorial-2-update.md

# Work against the release branch

> [!NOTE]
> You must have a [GitHub account linked with your Microsoft account](xref:access) and permissions to any of the
> repositories listed in this tutorial.
Now that you've created a release branch, let people know the branch name you created above. They should create topic
branches against that branch - just like they would against the `main` branch - and submit pull requests (PR).
Read about [API design](xref:api-design) for guidelines and more information.
- :white_check_mark: Create a topic branch from the upstream release branch.
- :white_check_mark: Submit a PR when ready against the upstream release branch.
- :x: Do not merge the `main` branch into your topic branch. If you need specific changes, you can cherry-pick them,
  or simply copy and paste.

## Create a fork

1. Create a fork, which is a copy of the target repository. You only need to do this once.
   - In [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs) (public) or  
     [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr) (private) - wherever you created
     your branch above - click on the **Fork** button if you haven't already forked the repository.
     This will create a copy in developers' own profiles. Read more about [our repositories](xref:api-repos) for what is
     public and what is private.
   - Click the **Clone** button to clone the repository to your local machine. You can also just hit `.` on
     GitHub to open the repository in Visual Studio Code online.
2. Whatever tool you use, switch branches to the release branch created above, and then create a new branch.
   Call it whatever you like, but a brief, descriptive name like `add-models` is recommended.
   Using a terminal, for example, you can pull the upstream release branch and create a topic branch:
   \`\`\`bash
   git fetch upstream release-cognitiveservices-2022-03-01-preview
   git checkout -b add-models upstream/release-cognitiveservices-2022-03-01-preview
   \`\`\`

Start working on your TypeSpec files.

Follow instructions on [Create your REST API definition](xref:api-specs?tabs=openapi)
#### Start working on your new OpenAPI specs
Make the desired changes on your new OpenAPI specification files.

### [Update OpenAPI specs](#tab/update-openapi)

Update the OpenAPI specification files directly."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"docs#develop#sdk-generate-mgmt-dotnet.md","document_title":"Generate .NET management plane SDK","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-generate-mgmt-dotnet","content":"# Generate .NET management plane SDK
## Generate SDKs with OpenAPI
# docs#develop#sdk-generate-mgmt-dotnet.md

# Generate .NET management plane SDK

## Generate SDKs with OpenAPI

`Azure.ResourceManager.ServiceLinker` is being used as our prime example for OpenAPI.
1. Use any editor to open the `autorest.md` under `src` subfolder, and update:
    - Go to the [ServiceLinker readme.md in Azure REST API Specs Repo](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/servicelinker/resource-manager/readme.md), press 'Y' key to [get the permanent link](https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/working-with-files/using-files/getting-permanent-links-to-files) and substitute the `require` value with your specific path here:
\`\`\`
require: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/{guid}/specification/servicelinker/resource-manager/readme.md
\`\`\`
> [!NOTE]
>  * You can use a local patch as the value, which allows you to test an unpublished local OpenAPI spec.
>  * When releasing your SDKs, it must refer to [the `main` branch of the public Azure REST API specs repository](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/specification). Other branches, private repos, or personal repos are **NOT** supported to release an official Azure SDK.
>  * If you need to generate SDKs from specs in [the private REST API Specs repo](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr), there is [an extra step to handle the credential for autorest](https://github.com/Azure/autorest/blob/main/docs/generate/readme.md#generate-from-private-github-repos).
    - Specify a target version using `tag` as belows if you don't want to use the default tag in [the README configuration file](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/samplefiles/README.md). For example,
\`\`\`
tag: package-2022-01-01-preview
\`\`\`
> [!NOTE]
> To ensure the preview of the corresponding .NET SDK in the API Spec PR, refrain from adding the tag here. Instead, use the default tag to generate the SDK and preview it as desired.

- Specify a target version using `tag` as belows if you don't want to use the default tag in [the README configuration file](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/samplefiles/README.md). For example,
\`\`\`
tag: package-2022-01-01-preview
\`\`\`
> [!NOTE]
> To ensure the preview of the corresponding .NET SDK in the API Spec PR, refrain from adding the tag here. Instead, use the default tag to generate the SDK and preview it as desired.
2. Run `dotnet build` command to generate the SDK code, then AutoRest will create your .NET SDK using the latest version of your API specs.
\`\`\`
dotnet build /t:GenerateCode
\`\`\`
> [!NOTE]
> Currently there could be some compatibility issues that the AutoRest tool can't handle. If you encounter generation errors, file an issue in the GitHub Repo [Azure/azure-sdk-for-net](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net) to get support.
3. Generate the API file with the following command, review it and update any SDK API if it does not follow the [.NET Azure SDK Design Guidelines](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/dotnet_introduction.html) with [mgmt configurations](https://github.com/Azure/autorest.csharp/blob/feature/v3/docs/mgmt/readme.md#management-plane-configurations) in `autorest.md`. Then regenerate the API file.
\`\`\`
<RepoRoot>\eng\scripts\Export-API.ps1 servicelinker
\`\`\`
:point_right: Replace `servicelinker` with your SDK service directory name under azure-sdk-for-net\sdk.
4. Once the SDK is generated, build your project either in VS or from command line (follow steps in the section [Build & test SDKs](#build--test-sdks)"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"docs#design#api-specs-pr#api-tutorial#api-tutorial-1-branch.md","document_title":"Create a new branch","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-tutorial/api-tutorial-1-branch","content":"# Create a new branch
# docs#design#api-specs-pr#api-tutorial#api-tutorial-1-branch.md

# Create a new branch

You'll first want to create a new branch in which to do your work and that everyone working on changes can target.
We support different type of branches. To learn more about them see [here](xref:api-versions-and-branches).
- :white_check_mark: Create a separate branch for each release that a team can work on together, whether
preview or stable.
- :ballot_box_with_check: Consider customizing the branch name to something discoverable, memorable, and consistent.
> [!Note]
> This tutorial uses the *release* branch, which has branch protection rules against it. Learn more about the different
> branches and branch protection rules [here](xref:api-versions-and-branches).

## How to create a new release branch

1. Clone the [repository](xref:api-repos) where you want the API spec to be published
2. Create a new release branch manually:

### [Public repo](#tab/public-repo)

\`\`\`
git branch <branch-name> main
\`\`\`

### [Private repo](#tab/private-repo)

In the private repo you can use `main`, `RPSaaSMaster` or `RPSaaSDev` as the base branch.
\`\`\`
git branch <branch-name> <base-branch>

rows.outputs.similarity.similarity_sample_inp: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: Target Branch Selection for Onboarding New Resource Types\\n\\nquestion: General I have created a PR to onboard new resource types. Is this the right target branch?\\nI was suggested to use azure-rest-api-specs-pr/RPSaaSMaster (private) Or azure-rest-api-specs/main (public) as the target branch?\\nI am getting branch protection error with the current PR.\\nLink to PR : https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/23390\\nThank you for the help!\", \"response\": \"You should target the appropriate release branch in the correct repository based on whether your onboarding is for a private or public API spec. For onboarding new resource types:\\n\\n- If your API spec is not yet public, you should use the private repo (azure-rest-api-specs-pr) and target either 'RPSaaSMaster' or 'RPSaaSDev' as your base branch. These branches are specifically designated for private onboarding and development before public release.\\n- If your API spec is ready for public onboarding, you should use the public repo (azure-rest-api-specs) and target the 'main' branch.\\n\\nBranch protection errors typically occur if you attempt to merge directly into a protected branch (such as 'main' or 'RPSaaSMaster') without following the required process. The correct workflow is:\\n1. Create a topic branch from the appropriate release branch (e.g., 'RPSaaSMaster' in private repo or 'main' in public repo).\\n2. Submit your PR against the release branch, not directly against 'main' or 'RPSaaSMaster'.\\n\\nThis ensures compliance with branch protection rules and allows for proper review and CI validation. If you are getting a branch protection error, double-check that your PR is not trying to merge directly into a protected branch. Instead, create a topic branch off the release branch and submit your PR against it.\\n\\nSummary:\\n- Use 'RPSaaSMaster' in azure-rest-api-specs-pr for private onboarding.\\n- Use 'main' in azure-rest-api-specs for public onboarding.\\n- Always create a topic branch from the release branch and submit your PR against the release branch, not directly into protected branches.\\n\\nIf you need more details on how to create and work against release branches, see the referenced onboarding documentation.\", \"ground_truth\": \"When onboarding new resource types (especially for ARM/Control Plane APIs), the right target branch depends on the stage of your API and whether your work should be public or private:\\nIf your resource types are still under development or in private preview (not ready for public visibility), you should target the RPSaaSMaster branch in the private repo: azure-rest-api-specs-pr.\\nOnce your API is ready for public preview or GA, you should target the main branch in the public repo: azure-rest-api-specs.\\nYou mentioned getting a branch protection error. This is likely because the main branch in the private repo is read-only and mirrored from the public repo. You cannot merge directly into main in the private repo. For private work, use RPSaaSMaster. For public release, use main in the public repo.\\nSummary:\\nUse azure-rest-api-specs-pr/RPSaaSMaster for private onboarding and early-stage work.\\nUse azure-rest-api-specs/main for public onboarding and final publishing.\\nIf you need to update your PR, change the target branch to RPSaaSMaster in the private repo for onboarding new resource types. If your resource is ready for public consumption, move it to a PR against the public repo's main branch.\\nLet me know if you need help updating your PR or have questions about the process!\"}"}]
